title.narrative: International Institute of Social Studies - Task Team Feb 2017-Mar 2019
International Institute of Social Studies - Task Team feb 2017-mar 2019

description.narrative:
International Institute of Social Studies (ISS), beläget i Haag, är en internationell forskarskola med politiskt inriktad samhällsvetenskap som hör samman med Erasmus University Rotterdam. ISS är värd för Task Team Secretariat (TTS) och har begärt en förlängning på 1 370 993 EUR (cirka 13 200 000 SEK) för att TTS ska fortsätta att stödja Task Teams (TT) arbete med frågor rörande den miljö civilsamhället verkar i, samt med frågor rörande civilsamhällets utvecklings- och biståndseffektivitet. Sida är den enda finansiären.
Task Teamet (TT) skapades i april 2009 inom Working Party on Aid Effectiveness. Det lanserades för att främja och övervaka genomförandet av de åtaganden som rör det civila samhället i 2008 års Accra Agenda for Action (AAA) och 2008 års rekommendationer (utarbetade av Advisory Group on Civil Society and Aid Effectiveness). Från 2008 till 2011 underlättade TT utbyte mellan CSO, partnerländer och leverantörer av utvecklingsbistånd om konsekvenserna av dessa åtaganden. Efter högnivåforumet i Busan förnyade arbetsgruppen sitt självdefinierade mandat som ett frivilligt initiativ i samband med det globala partnerskapet för effektivt utvecklingssamarbete (GPEDC). GPECD skapade ett övervakningsramverk bestående av 10 indikatorer, varav Indicator Two är: "Det civila samhället arbetar inom en miljö som maximerar sitt engagemang och bidrag till utvecklingen."
TT består av företrädare för tre intressegrupper: givare, partnerländer och civilsamhällen. TT har cirka 28 aktiva deltagare och många affiliates, och strävar efter ungefär lika delaktighet från sina tre huvudaktörsgrupper. TT har för närvarande tre medordförande: Representanter från presidentens kontor i Mali, Nederländernas utrikesdepartement samt CSO-partnerskapet för utvecklingseffektivitet (CPDE) som Sida också stöder. TT arbetar för att förfina och övervaka GPEDC:s indikator 2 och skapa medvetenhet på alla nivåer om vikten av ett gott stöd till civilsamhällsdonering.
Den övergripande målsättningen för Task Teamet för perioden 2017–2018 är att fortsatt bidra till förbättrad biståndseffektivitet genom att öka förståelsen för och efterlevnaden av internationella åtaganden i Accra, Busan och Mexico City. Målsättningen är också att dessa åtaganden beaktas i utarbetandet av Agenda 2030.
Förlängningen av TTS:s verksamhet grundar sig på en förnyad TT-strategi. Under TT-mötet i London i maj 2016 diskuterades olika scenarier för framtida TT-positionering, vilket också reflekterades i halvtidsöversynen:
- Påverka olika forum, särskilt GPEDC och Agenda 2030. TT och GPEDC anser dessa två domäner som parallella men kompletterande spår i sina ansträngningar att påverka. TT ska leta efter kreativa kopplingar mellan de två arenorna. - Ha en aktiv roll i skapandet av kunskapsprodukter relaterade till sin agenda. - Vara mer aktiv samt mer relevant på land- och regionalnivå.

The International Institute of Social Studies (ISS), located in The Hague, is an international research school with political-oriented social sciences associated with Erasmus University Rotterdam. ISS is hosting the Task Team Secretariat (TTS) and has requested an extension of EUR 1,370,993 (about 13,200,000 SEK) for TTS to continue to support Task Teams (TT) work on issues related to the environment in which civil society operates, as well as with issues relating to civil society development and aid effectiveness. Sida is the only financier.
The Task Team (TT) was created in April 2009 within the Working Party on Aid Effectiveness. It was launched to promote and monitor the implementation of civil society commitments in the 2008 Accra Agenda for Action (AAA) and 2008 recommendations (prepared by the Advisory Group on Civil Society and Aid Effectiveness). From 2008 to 2011, TT facilitated exchanges between CSO, partner countries and development assistance providers regarding the consequences of these commitments. Following the High Level Forum in Busan, the Working Group renewed its self-defined mandate as a voluntary initiative in the context of the Global Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation (GPEDC). GPECD created a monitoring framework consisting of 10 indicators, of which Indicator Two is: "Civil society works in an environment that maximizes its commitment and contribution to development."
TT consists of representatives of three interest groups: donors, partner countries and civil society. TT has approximately 28 active participants and many affiliates, and strives for approximately equal participation from its three main actors. TT currently has three co-chairmen: Representatives from the Presidential Office in Mali, the Netherlands Department of Foreign Affairs and the CSD Development Efficiency (CPDE) Partnership, which Sida also supports. TT works to refine and monitor GPEDC's indicator 2 and raise awareness at all levels. The overall objective of the Task Team for the 2017-2018 period is to continue to contribute to improved aid effectiveness by increasing understanding and compliance with international commitments in Accra, Busan and Mexico City. The objective is also to take these commitments into account in the preparation of Agenda 2030.
The extension of TTS's operations is based on a renewed TT strategy. During the TT meeting in London in May 2016, different scenarios were discussed for future TT positioning, as reflected in the mid-term review:
- Affect different forums, especially GPEDC and Agenda 2030. TT and GPEDC consider these two domains to be parallel but complementary in their efforts to influence. TT will look for creative links between the two arenas. - Have an active role in the creation of knowledge products related to their agenda. - Be more active and more relevant at country and regional level.

The continued support during 2017 - 2018 to the International Institute of Social Studies (ISS) for support to the Task Team Secretariat seeks to further strengthen CSO Development Effectiveness and Enabling Environment through fora including the Global Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation (GPEDC) and Agenda 2030.

description.narrative: -Overall, TT has shown weakness in achieving clear results during the project period. The focus of this interimperiod was on information-gathering and strategy development, which TT expresses in a transparent manner and attribute the lack of results to the need for this interim period. The internal results TT achieved in terms of output include a renewed Task Team strategy 2018-2021, the Task Team Guiding Principles and a new funding proposal. -External results achieved in terms of output includes a 70-page report, "Guidance and Good Practice on CSO Development Effectiveness and Enabling Environment" (the Guidance), which TT offered as a contribution to the GPEDC work on the inclusive partner principle. A 40-page Abstract of the Guidance was also developed. These both serve as a basis for the country-level workshops that TT intend to hold. While these two Guidances was the result, the original intent was to help refine indicator 2 of the GPEDC monitoring framework and produce a specific Guidance on indicator 2, which TT also contributed to. The Guidance was included in the GPEDCs own "Compendium of Good Practice" which accounts for as a result. -TT also achieved to support Honduras in developing a roadmap for development efficiency. As well as assisting government officials with multi-stakeholder dialogue during the Development Effectiveness Forum in July 2017. -The task team Strategy was finalized later than initially planned, resulting in a delayed process of the funding proposal.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
